Title: Wage stagnation and the rise of merit pay, 1974-1991
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: From the 1970s to the early 1990s, US workers' wages stopped growing. During this time, employers experimented with practices, like merit-based pay increases, that seemed likely to raise pay. We argue on the contrary that merit pay weakened organizational constraints that previously boosted wages. First, merit pay practices loosen pay fairness constraints. Second, merit pay substitutes for efficiency wages, by providing an alternative mechanism through which employers can elicit worker effort. We introduce new establishment-by-occupation microdata covering the critical early period of wage stagnation. The analysis demonstrates that organizational practices can aggregate up to affect societal trends in wage growth. © 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020. All rights reserved.

Title: Who can start a stock exchange? Silent legitimacy, mundane materiality and the genesis of markets
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: This study considers the genesis and development of two stock markets established in London in 1995. It draws on elite interviews and documentary sources to explore how the founders of these markets sought to legitimize them as stable, durable venues for security trade. The study uses insights from the STS-inflected study of markets to present an account of legitimacy as embedded in taken-for-granted socio-material structures. We term this phenomenon 'silent legitimacy'. Contributing to a nascent 'material turn' in institutional theory, we argue that the markets-as-institutions literature can be strengthened through attention to the mundane material dimensions of institutional fields. © 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020. Title: The power of expressed humility: Investors' reaction to humble entrepreneurs
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: We conduct a randomized field experiment examining how an entrepreneur's expressed humility affects venture capitalists' willingness to fund his/her venture. While high humility is often associated with effective leadership and constructive behavior, it may also inhibit entrepreneurial action and generative behavior. Our findings show that early-stage investors perceive that humble entrepreneurs have higher constructive qualities and are more compatible with investors than non-humble entrepreneurs. Expressed humility has an overall positive effect on investors' evaluations of the venture's likelihood of success and their willingness to fund the venture. © 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020. All rights reserved.

Title: Multicultural and multilingual individuals forming social capital
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: Our explorative, qualitative study investigates how multicultural and multilingual employees form social capital. Based on the analysis of 154 semi-structured interviews, we develop a model that shows the multifaceted process how multilinguals form language-specific social capital only, whereas multiculturals form culture-specific but also culture-general social capital. Our inductive reasoning unpacks, next to the language- and culture-related attributes also personal characteristics that these individuals draw on when forming social capital. Our study contributes to international business research by introducing the micro-processes of forming social capital and expanding knowledge about the resources that multicultural and multilingual employees bring to organizations. © 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020. Title: Rumelt (1991) revisited: Does industry really matter more than corporate?
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: In a seminal article, Rumelt (1991) conducted variance components analysis on a sample of U.S. firms from 1974 to 1977 and concluded that corporate effects have almost no importance in explaining variation of firm performance. Follow-up studies using different methodologies and time periods found much larger corporate effects. Replicating Rumelt's methodology reveals that the original study's results can be reproduced, however, corporate effects have been gradually increasing in importance since the 1980s and are now larger than industry effects. This implies that multi-business firms today should be more concerned with building corporate advantages rather than simply operating in good industries. © 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020. All rights reserved.

Title: Connectivity and cohesion in the networked world: A durkheimian perspective
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: This paper addresses the challenge of maintaining social cohesion through waves of potentially disruptive technological innovations. It develops concepts from Durkheim's Division of Labour to advance theoretical understanding of the relationship between individual connectivity and emergence of a coherent network society. Durkheim's concepts help elucidate how we can mitigate that risk by maintaining social cohesion in the absence of established norms. © 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020. Title: Extending the job crafting theory: A mixed methods investigation

Abstract: A mixed-methods study was employed to investigate the motivational determinants of job crafting. Title: Does remixing facilitate user innovation? An exploratory study of an online 3D printing platform
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: Many users join online makerspace communities to design and share their creation. These online platforms often encourage remixing (i.e. reusing and modifying prior works). Is remixing beneficial for user innovation? This study offers a quantitative analysis of more than 67,000 3D models in the world's largest online 3D printing community. Findings reveal that 3D models derived from prior models are more novel and diffuse better than models created from scratch (i.e. not remixed). However, remixing too many models increases product uniqueness but hamper product novelty and product diffusion. © 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020. Title: The role of trainer characteristics in intern sexual harassment training effectiveness
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: Sexual harassment has received considerable attention over the last several years and poses serious problems for both employees and employers. Research aimed to prevent it has largely focused on sexual harassment training. However, design choices in computer-based training remains under-researched. We highlight three training design factors, (1) media richness, (2) the trainer's biological sex, and (3) the trainer's area of expertise, that influence training outcomes, mediated by perceived trainer integrity. Our findings show that in text-based training, depicting trainers with gender-incongruent expertise results in decreased training effectiveness, mediated by perceived trainer integrity. Title: Friends in low places: Status, structure and venture capital syndicate performance
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: While alliance and venture capital studies find a halo effect for high-status partners and a positive impact on performance, they have not considered the potential interaction of alliance role structure and status and its impact on performance. Abstract: Many organizations experience traumatic events over the course of their history which result in the disruption of key organizational activities. Abstract: Turnover research has extensively documented negative effects of turnover on organizations. Abstract: We combine team effectiveness and governance theories to investigate the complex relationships between board diversity, processes, strategic involvement and corporate performance. Abstract: Policy alienation exists when public professionals feel they have little influence on policy implementation (powerlessness), or when they feel a policy is meaningless. Title: Race to the top: Collective reputation crisis and firm certification behavior

Abstract: Firms use certification programs to improve operation efficiency and product quality, and thus maximize firm long-term profitability. The findings suggest firms engage in over-certification that hurt firm profitability and fail to lead to the improvement of product quality. Title: Resilience does matter: A meta-analysis of trait resilience outcomes in the organizational setting
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: Trait resilience is defined as assets or strengths helping resilient individuals to adapt in the face of adversity. In this study, the effect of trait resilience on life and work outcomes and the boundary conditions of these effects were investigated in the organizational setting by conducting a meta-analysis. The results indicate that trait resilience is moderately linked with psychological-level outcomes, and the type of occupation seems to explain some of the heterogeneity in burnout. Title: Emerging market institutional co-evolution, state-owned firm globalization and the resource curse
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: We explore natural resource “curse” effects on co-evolutionary relationships between emerging economy institutions and the internationalization of their state-owned enterprises. These relationships challenge and extend prior institutional research because of three predominant resource curse characteristics (boom-and-bust cycles and related public discourse, and “Dutch Disease”-associated manufacturing sector investment crowd-out). In this environment, state-owned enterprise ties with emerging economy regulative, normative and cognitive institutions moderate the firm's internationalization over the emerging economy's resource curse cycle. Title: Pursuing greater good by reducing power: CEO humility, TMT decentralization, and ethical culture.
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: Humility is increasingly recognized as a highly important attribute for strategic leaders to build successful organizations. However, research on CEO humility has focused on how humble CEOs shape collective perceptions through their interactions and behaviors with other organizational members while ignoring CEOs' critical role in strategic decision-making processes. We address this unexplored aspect of CEO humility by developing a process theory that explains how humble CEOs influence power decentralization at the TMT and subsequently promote organizational ethical culture. Title: When does a daily dose of nature matter? Linking extra-work contact with nature to employee behavior
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: Research indicates that contact with nature at work has beneficial effects on employees. We examine the effects of daily contact with nature before and after work on beginning of day employee affect and work effort later in the day. Our results indicate that exposure to nature before work positively affects employees' beginning of day moods and subsequent work effort. Prior evening contact with nature also positively related to beginning of workday affect and subsequent work effort, but only for employees with high levels of nature connectedness-an individual difference that relates to individuals' innate connection to the natural world. © 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020. Title: The effect of tariffs on inventory performance: The moderating role of supply base characteristics
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: Tariffs have taken a prominent role in the recent news cycle as politicians around the world have increasingly enacted protectionist trade policy to incentivize reshoring and local sourcing. Our study seeks to understand what impact tariffs have on inventory levels and inventory leanness using data from the auto industry. We also explore the moderating impact dimensions of supply base complexity on the relationship between tariffs and inventory. Our findings indicate that tariffs are associated with higher inventory levels and less lean supply chains. We also find that there are several complexity dimensions which can reduce the impact of these tariffs. © 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020. Title: New venture creation and the development of entrepreneurial cognition: A longitudinal analysis of startup diaries
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: Entrepreneurs engage in sensemaking activities continuously during new venture creation. We followed 30 entrepreneurs who were starting their ventures at an incubator-accelerator setting. These founders wrote weekly diaries over a period of one year reflecting on their experience. We studied specific instances in these diary entries where the entrepreneurs reported sensebreaking - the creation of a meaning void - and subsequent sensemaking through their interaction with different stakeholders within and outside the incubator. We describe novel sensemaking that follows sensebreaking via three different mechanisms namely, reframing, redirecting and questioning. Title: CEO positive framing and employee participation in esops
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: This study investigates the influence of CEO positive framing in public speeches on employee participation in ESOPs. CEO positive framing can increase employee ownership when employees internalize CEOs' positive beliefs about firms' accomplishments and prospects, but can also decrease employee ownership when employees question the credibility of CEOs' positive framing. Using a sample of 3,144 U.S. listed firms from 2002 to 2013, we find that CEO positive framing increases employee participation in ESOPs. Title: Converting inventions into innovations in large firms: How inventors at xerox navigated the innovation process to commercialize their ideas

Abstract: The challenges of commercializing breakthrough inventions in large firms have been studied through a lens of managerial decision-making. Title: Banking for a low carbon future: Explaining variation in corporate climate change responses in a low-salience industry
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: We present a qualitative comparative case study of four European banks, investigating mechanisms that help or hinder the integration of climate change (CC) considerations in the banks' corporate strategies. We find that strategic CC responses are dependent on the following factors: the initial interpretation of the CC issue, the language deployed to advocate for CC and the governance structures that are being invoked (or not) to spread attention to CC both within the bank and to external constituents. Title: Arrested development: Organizational and entrepreneurial sensemaking in a maker space
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: Through an inductive study of a maker space, the latest form of entrepreneurial support organization (. ESO) focused on shared tool access and skill development, we identify three orientations that entrepreneurs adopt in the organization: “Instrumental”; “Communal”; “Experimental.” Instrumentalist and Communalist entrepreneurs experience a “cycle of entrenchment” as the maker space limits entrepreneurial sensemaking and encourages dependency over time. Alternatively, Experimentalist entrepreneurs experience a “cycle of self-defeat,” slowly withdrawing from the space as doubt grows about themselves and their venture. Title: In the space between the group and the individual: The microfoundations of intragroup conflict
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: Scholars have historically assumed that intragroup conflict exists primarily at the team level. Emerging evidence suggests, however, that perceptions of intragroup conflict are oftentimes not uniform, shared, or static. This raises questions about whether conflict emerges at the individual level, or in the space between the group and the individual (e.g., dyad or subgroup). We address these questions in a field study investigating task and relationship conflict in manufacturing teams. Results indicate that conflict exists primarily at the dyadic-level, followed by the individual and subgroup-level origins, with minimal conflict at the full team-level. © 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020. Title: Learning in collectives: How maker spaces encourage entrepreneurship and innovation
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: This study examines the conditions under which participation in maker space organizations increases the entrepreneurial and innovative activities of individuals and firms. Title: Life after death: Implications of bereavement for the post-succession phase in family businesses
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: In this study, we explore how the process of coping with bereavement, following the death of a family business leader, affects the way a family business is managed by the family successor during the post-succession stage. The death of a family business leader is a stressful event, and family successors need to adapt to their new role while simultaneously dealing with the loss of a loved one. Title: Towards degrowth-conform organizational models. Framework development and application
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: Business activity is a key driving force behind economic growth. Title: The sharing economy landscape: Structuring research from airbnb to ZIPCAR
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: The sharing economy has aroused the interest from both practitioners and researchers from a variety of disciplines. We contribute to the literature by: 1) textually analyzing which topic areas previous research has focused on; 2) describe interlinkages among the topic areas; and 3) providing directions on how future research can draw on previously used theories to lift sharing economy research towards a theory-driven debate. © 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020. Title: Issue framing and environmental performance: The moderating effect of board age
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: Do firms conceive of imperatives to improve their environmental performance as threats to their current activities or as opportunities to do things in better and more sustainable ways? We find that significant environmental performance improvements of firms with older boards are more likely to arise when they perceive of material physical and regulatory climate risks. Title: The role of a lmx defining memory and relationship emotions in leader-follower relationships
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: Research in the fields of organizational science, neuroscience, and cognitive psychology underscore the importance of autobiographical memory. Title: Testing the efficacy and mechanisms of an authentic self-expression orientation in enhancing newcomer job performance: A longitudinal quasi-field experiment
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: Building on a prior research (Cable, Gino, & Staats, 2013), the present study further tests the effectiveness of the authentic self-expression orientation, with a focus on the dynamic treatment effects on socialization outcomes (i.e., perceived stress, popularity, and job performance). Title: Succeeding against the odds: Insights from successful female leaders in kosovo, where 8 out of 10 women stay home
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: What impediments do women who aspire to lead face in a highly patriarchal society? Title: The influence of entrepreneurial teams' structual power inequality on firm performance
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: We investigate how structural power inequality within entrepreneurial teams influences firm performance. Title: Intelligent machines and teamwork: Help or hindrance?

Abstract: Whereas research has examined how AI affects individual work, few studies explore the impact on task-performing teams. Title: Illuminating secrecy in corporate political activity
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: Law-abiding firms often conceal their political activity (CPA). Our framework analyzes the circumstances that prompt firms to do so. Our framework addresses multiple levels of analysis including firms, markets, state agencies, political issues, and institutional systems. Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: There is a widespread perception that Chinese companies are not good at creating novel products and services. Title: Historical protestant influence, subnational institutions, and organizational structure in the U.S.
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020

Abstract: This study explores how multi-segment and single-segment competitive positions within an industry are affected by changes in market frictions. Abstract: The literature on corporate sustainability continues to grow, but the issue itself remains difficult to navigate. Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: The purpose of this paper is to develop theory on and investigate how an organization's provisions of resources, employees' perceived intentions behind the provisions, and the effects of work on employee well-being collectively influence the quality of the employee-organization relationship. Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: As climate change pervades natural and social systems, the integration of social sciences in interdisciplinary climate change research is crucial but often lacking. Title: There is no lean in for men
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: In popularized leadership discourse, in leadership development circles, and in much of leadership research, the counterpoint to “women's leadership” is not “men's leadership,” but just plain, “leadership.” We explore the discursive and gendered politics behind the stark divide between women's leadership and the relative non-existence of men's leadership as a comparable topic of concern. Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: The success of open innovation depends on the individuals that stand at the interface of the firm and its external partners. Adopting an attention-based view, we investigate the influence of organizational context and context changes on individual-level search openness trajectories and explore performance implications of such trajectories. © 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020. Title: Rare is beautiful? Rare technological resources and value implications
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: We examine firms' choice of rare R&D topics and the development of technological resources. We build our theory exploiting the fundamental tension in the technology factor market. Abstract: While prior literature takes the positive relationship between corporate social responsibility (CSR) and social license (SL) for granted, this study examines its boundary conditions. Abstract: Employees regularly face incivility at work, and this behavior has been linked to negative outcomes for both organizations and individuals. Title: Academic spin-off resource mobilization and performance: The role of social, economic and hybrid goals
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: We know little about how diversity in organizational goals influence the behavior and performance of new ventures. The goal of creating societal impacts is particularly salient in academic spin-offs (ASOs) seeking to commercialize scientific research. Building on the behavioral theory of the firm, we hypothesize that the initial goals of ASOs influence resource mobilization and performance. Using a unique longitudinal dataset of 275 ASOs in Norway, we find that initial goal orientation is a predictor of resource mobilization behavior and performance. Our findings have substantial implications for conceiving and theorizing hybrid goals and blended value creation in entrepreneurship. © 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020. Title: Institutional strengthening as ethical obligation: An agonistic approach to business ethics
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: Business ethics scholars often write about institutions as relatively static guidelines with which companies may or may not comply. We argue that conceiving of institutions in this way limits the role they can play in addressing conflict. We draw from work by political theorist Chantal Mouffe on agonism, applying it to business ethics. We develop the notion of agonistic business responsibility, which overcomes existing limitations in the literature by legitimizing stakeholder voices and recognizing that greater corporate legitimacy could arise through contestation. © 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020. Title: Whyte-out: How the creator of groupthink became unseen by management's history
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: Irving Janis' (1971) concept of 'groupthink', the idea that a desire for consensus overrides the realistic appraisals of alternatives and leads to poor decision making, is a staple of management textbooks. What has been forgotten, however, is that nearly 20 years before Janis' supposed invention, groupthink was created by William H. Whyte, author of one of the 1950s' most influential and popular books on management. We investigate how Whyte's link to groupthink became invisible to management's history, why this matters, and how recovering Whyte's ideas can provide critical new insights. © 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020. Title: The good fight: Constructive conflict by design
Source title: 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020
Abstract: Deliberative democracy has received growing attention in business ethics as well as in management and organization studies. We consider dialogue a central feature of such deliberation and explore how participants in collaborative housing (cohousing) organizations engage in dialogue to manage conflict while seeking consent or consensus. Our findings suggest that several mechanisms and processes contribute to the creation of a context that favors dialogue: self-selection, training, facilitation, a space for managing tensions, and agonism. The commitment to making use of consent/consensus-seeking processes in this context can direct members towards deliberative processes that induce productive dialogue. © 80th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2020: Understanding the Inclusive Organization, AoM 2020.
